turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Lovely sound- they seem happy.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Don't they, though?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: So work must be going well?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Truthfully?  There has been the occasional odd hiccup- but then, as you so wisely told me, I'd never built in Africa.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: But overall, you're pleased?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: I do need to see Starling.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Starling?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Awhile back he ordered some bibles-  -I've brought them.  Is he here?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Yes he is.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Well, I need to speak to him.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: It's what the natives are calling the lions-  -two lions have been causing trouble-

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: -what's the surprise in that, this is Africa?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: It hasn't been that simple so far.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: What have they done besides kill Starling?  How many have they killed?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: This is supposed to be salvation?  What kind of idiocy are we dealing with here?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I'm calling it my "contraption"- we're going to surround it with a boma- a fence, to you- and we're going to leave a small opening opposite that door.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: In that half will be bait- human bait- I'll start things off-  -a sliding door will fit above that and a trip wire will run across the floor.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Genius- the beast will enter, tripping the wire, the door will slide down, trapping him, you, safe behind the bars, will have him at your mercy and will shoot him.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Are you running a high fever, man? How could you expect something as lunatic as this to succeed? How could you even conceive of it?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I didn't conceive of it for the lions- I built one in India when there was trouble with a tiger.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: And it worked?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: In point of fact, it didn't.  But I'm convinced the theory is sound.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: I made a mistake hiring you- you're simply not up to the job.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: You genuinely enjoy trying to terrify people, don't you? Well, fine-  -except there isn't a higher rated engineer and we both know that. And since time is so important to you, how long do you think it would take to find someone else qualified and bring him here?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Let me explain about time- you've been here three months and already two months behind. And the Germans and the French are gearing up. And I don't care about you and I don't care about the thirty dead- I care about my knighthood and if this railroad finishes on schedule, I'll get my knighthood and I want it.  Professional hunters may be the answer.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: All they'll bring is more chaos and we've plenty of that already- and if they come in, word will get out- and what happens to your knighthood then?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: I'm going to try and locate Redbeard- I assume you've heard of him.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Every man who's ever fired a rifle has heard of him- by the time you find him, the lions will be dead.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Very well, the job's still yours, I'll go. But if I have to return, you're finished. And I will then do everything I can to destroy your reputation. Am I not fair?  Told you you'd hate me.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Understand, I had help-

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: -not a time for modesty, Bob-

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: This sham? Ridiculous. Who needs it? It's only being built to control the ivory trade, make men richer.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Then why do you stay?

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: Who else would hire me?  Beat you to it, didn't I?  Oh yes, almost forgot- brought you a little welcoming gift.

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: I know it's your first day and of course you must be tired from the journey-  -but what are you going to do about it?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Karim will have to show me where it happened. And of course, I'll need the donkey.  With any luck, I'll sort it out tonight.

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: You're certain about tomorrow?  But you don't seem excited.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: You don't enjoy killing, do you?

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: Then why do it?

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: I'm David Hawthorne, this is my hospital. And my advice to you is, "don't get sick in front of it."  That was meant to be charming, sorry. I seem to have lost the knack.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: You never had it.

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: Nigel and I don't like each other much.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: A man-eater attacks and you're such a buffoon you almost forget to mention it?

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: Well, he got away, didn't he?  Riding a donkey not far from here when the lion sprang on them- donkey took the brunt of it- then suddenly the lion ran off.

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: -then he feasted on him, starting with his feet-

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: -please- you needn't be so graphic-

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: You intend "sorting this out" tonight?

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: That's a terrible idea-

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: -is it, I'm sorry, but then, of course, you're the doctor, you should know.

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: Silliest thing I ever heard of- why in the world should we go through all that?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: I suppose I could answer you. I suppose I could explain that the place is so inviting, what with the smell of blood and flesh, that they have to strike. It's even possible that I tell you I found some fresh paw marks around back which means they're already contemplating feasting here.  But I don't want to answer you because when you question me you are really saying that I don't have the least idea what I am doing, that I am nothing but an incompetent, that I am a fool.  Anyone who finds me a fool, please say so now.

turns.speaker: HAWTHORNE
turns.text: I have been desperate for Patterson to let me move the hospital since the day he arrived.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Then we agree.

turns.speaker: HELENA
turns.text: I tried to be late, John- it would have been easier if you'd gone.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: We're not much good at goodbyes, Helena.

turns.speaker: HELENA
turns.text: Tell me about Beaumont- does he understand how brilliant you are, how lucky he is to have you?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: It was embarrassing- the man showered me with compliments.

turns.speaker: HELENA
turns.text: Oh dear-  -you're geting that downtrodden look again-

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: -well, it's just...  ...other men don't abandon their wives at such a time-

turns.speaker: HELENA
turns.text: -oh please- if I'd been against your taking this, you would have abandoned me. You've been desperate to see Africa your whole life.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: What if there are complications?-

turns.speaker: HELENA
turns.text: -not "what if"- there will be, there always are. Which only means that our "son" and I- note my confidence- will have an excuse to come visit.

turns.speaker: HELENA
turns.text: Go, now.  Such a gentleman.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I am desperate to see Africa- but I hate the leaving.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Very good indeed.

turns.speaker: MIDDLE COOLIE
turns.text: We have hunted since childhood.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: All right- you'll spend your nights inside.  You'll have plenty of ammunition. You're totally protected, you have really nothing to fear.

turns.speaker: MIDDLE COOLIE
turns.text: That is correct.  Nothing.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Not once?- you didn't hit it once?-

turns.speaker: MIDDLE COOLIE
turns.text: -I would never make excuses- but a fire broke out- the light was bad- he kept moving-

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: -well, of course he kept moving- but he couldn't have been more than ten feet away from the three of you- surely you must have wounded the thing-

turns.speaker: MIDDLE COOLIE
turns.text: I assure you we came close many times-

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Many thanks.  You're Patterson, yes?  Nigel Starling- I'll be assisting you at Tsavo- but surely Beaumont must have told you that.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: He just gave me his "monster" speech.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: That. I know Robert seems dreadful, but when you truly get to know the man, well, he's much worse.  And I'm one of his defenders.  Forget him for now- it's your first ride to Tsavo- I think you'll find it breathtaking.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Don't much like them.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: The females are bigger- only animal here like that- have to be or they wouldn't survive because the males eat the young.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Anything special about them?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Just that they fart through their mouths.  Must make kissing something of a gamble.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: I've lived in Africa a year and I don't know what you know. How long have you been here?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Almost three hours.  But I've been getting ready all my life.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Every time I see something like that, I know we're right to be here- to bring Christianity into their lives, enrich their souls.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Beaumont says it's to end slavery.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: We all have our reasons. Mine is simply to make them understand happiness, accept salvation, know the serenity that comes-  -best I stop. One of the by-products of my belief is that I can become amazingly boring. But I know God smiles on me.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Have you got that in writing?

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Samuel is camp liaison- absolutely indispensable- the only man here everyone trusts.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Does he speak English?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Excellent. Could I see the bridge site?

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: I've got medical supplies to deliver. Come along to the hospital when you're done.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Finish your tour?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: And anxious to get started.  What is this, mostly malaria?

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Yes- but their suffering is only transitory- once they except God into their hearts, He will vanquish all pain.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: I couldn't believe it when you said "sort it out." As if it were the most normal thing in the world. "Ho-hum, what lovely tea, I think I'll bag a killer beast this evening, nothing much else going on anyway."

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Well, he put me in a spot, didn't he? But that's all right- after all, I'm responsible for everything that happens here. And it certainly won't do much for morale if a man-eater's on the prowl.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: You said "of course" you'd need the donkey. Why "of course"?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: We know three things about man-eaters. First, they always return to where they've attacked before. Second, they're always old- they can't catch other animals so they turn to us. And third, they're always alone- they've been cast out by their pride because they can't keep up.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: I don't suppose I could watch.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Might be exciting for you.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: I've never been all that adventurous. I wouldn't be in the way?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I'd love the company. And I've hunted all my life.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Well, why not? You seem so calm and experienced.  Why not, indeed!

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: I hate to be a bother, John, but the cramp's getting worse.  The pain is actually quite unbearable now.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Shhh.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: I'm sure you mean that to be comforting, but-

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: -you'll have to deal with it, Nigel.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: That is precisely my plan- but back in my tent.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: John? I know this isn't the time to ask, but-

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Since you'd only been here three hours when we met, are you sure this is how you hunt lions?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Not to terrify you, Nigel, but it's worse than you think- I've never even seen one.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: ...one shot...

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: So that's what a lion looks like.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: With much more on the way-  -John- we could have had this chat on flatter ground-

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: -true enough- but without the comedy relief.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: How lucky we are.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: Aren't we full of ourselves today?  I think it's because of the lion.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Possibly.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: All right- thee second embankment will go there.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: You do plan to mark it a bit more precisely than just-  -"there."

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: In your honor, Nigel. And you and Singh will be in charge of building them- and you'll also build the roadbeds and the three foundation pillars- and you'll be finished in eight thrilling weeks.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: John, it will not be easy.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Nigel, you'll just have to use your hands-

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I'll try- but this feels so different- that old lion I killed could never carry off a man Singh's size.

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: But you said they were always old.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: That's what the books say...

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Second death? Where?-

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: -far end of camp- man wandering alone at night. Hawthorne's examining the body now.  There's even less of him than of Singh.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: But it's crazy- the lion shouldn't be that hungry this soon.  Samuel?

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: What a good week.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: You mean nobody died?

turns.speaker: STARLING
turns.text: We all worked together. Worthy deeds were accomplished. I liked the labor.  My mother insisted on piano lessons- broke the dear woman's heart when I turned out to be tone deaf- but she still was always at me about being careful with my hands.  I like the blood, is that strange?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I didn't have a chance to thank you.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: What did I do?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Got me out of trouble.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Nonsense- Samuel would have done something.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: We need to talk.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Let me save time-  you are the engineer;  you are in charge;  you're sorry I'm here. Right so far?  Good- because  I am not an engineer,  I don't want to be in charge, and  I'm sorrier than you are that I'm here- I hate Tsavo. So I will help you by killing the lions and leaving, and you will help me by doing what I tell you so I can leave. See any problems?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Actually, no.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: All right- let's go into battle.  I'm Redbeard.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Somehow I guessed.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: I don't really. But understand something- even though it may take me two or three days to sort this out-  -when I'm gone, you'll still have to build the bridge. And I don't want the men to have lost respect for you.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: That's very considerate.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: I'm always considerate- my mother taught me that.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Have you got it?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: No, but you do-  -see, you were needed after all.  And fifty warriors at the camp before dawn.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: The best way to ensure the kill when you're using trackers is for one to shoot while the other uses the trackers to force the lion toward the shooter. Have you ever led trackers?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I can try.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Samuel says you killed a lion.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: It was probably luck- I'd rather you did the shooting.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: You'd never force the lion to me- and nobody ever got a lion with one shot by luck.  Around there's a clearing- you'll know it from the anthills- get there and hide and listen to the sounds- I'll make the lion come directly to you.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: ...misfire... it jammed...

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Has it ever done that before?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: ...don't know...

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Think about something else.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Have you ever failed?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Only in life...

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Goddammit!

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: It's all right. Stay ready.  They know it's there.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Meant to ask you- the railroad car trap. Your idea?  Excellent notion- I used the same device myself once.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: But of course yours worked.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: In point of fact it didn't- but I'm convinced the idea is sound.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: It would have been a beautiful bridge, John. I never noticed before, occupied with other business, I	suppose...  ...never really pay much attention to that kind of thing but I've had the time today, nothing else on, and this... it's graceful and the placement couldn't be prettier... and...

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: You just got hit.  The getting up is up to you- but they're only lions-  -and I'm going after them crack of dawn...

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: In my town, when I was little, there was a brute, a bully who terrorized the place.  But he was not the problem. He had a brother who was worse than he. But the brother was not the problem.  One or the other of them was usually in jail. The problem came when they were both free togther. The two became different from either alone.  Alone they were only brutes. Together they became lethal, together they killed.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: What happened to them?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: I got big.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Their den?  Have you ever seen anything like this?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Nobody's seen anything like this. Lions don't have caves like this-  -they're doing it for pleasure.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Where could it have gone? How could it get across the water?  They're only lions, yes?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Don't they have to be?...

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: They're used to people in trees, not in a clearing.  It may be tight.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Not for me- I'm too bulky and it's your idea, you go up there.  Take the others to the water tower for the night.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I'll be bait alone?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Yes. And I'll be in some distant tree where I can provide no assistance whatsoever.  Can you control your fear?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I'll have to.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: I can't control mine- I'd be lost without the shame factor driving me.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Was that supposed to make me feel better?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: It's certainly the best chance they've had to kill you.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: You think they'll come then?  Why?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Good luck.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Because I think they're after you.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: How many do you think they've killed?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: The most of any lions... a hundred...?  Probably more.  Johnny...?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I never thought I'd say this, but I'm glad you came.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Understood- you realize now you could never have done it without me.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Actually, I could have done it much more easily without you, but for whatever reason, I'm glad you came.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Why do the workers look unhappy?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Because they are here.  Because Tsavo is the worst place in the world.  Come, John- to the bridge.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: It's all wonderfully under control, Samuel- you've done a splendid job.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Thank you. The truth is this: you have to work at it constantly.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: The workers don't get on?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Get on? They detest each other. Obviously the Africans hate the Indians. But the Indians also hate the other Indians. Some of them worship cows, while others eat them.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Did it look like this in your mind?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: This is more difficult-

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: I am also liaison between these two.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Clearly you don't agree about building the railroad?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: What are they looking at?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: You- they cannot believe you're still here.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Nonsense.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: You don't know what Tsavo means, do you?  It means "slaughter"...

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: We should construct thorn fences around every tent area. Fires burning at night.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Fine. Get started. And a strict curfew- no one allowed out at night.  Send half your men to the bridge, the rest with these two.  And I'm sorry for my tone earlier. But I repeat- there is no reason for fear. I will kill the lion and I will build the bridge.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Oh yes, I think so.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Look out, Samuel, here it comes.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: For you.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Thank you, Samuel.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Good news?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I expect so- it's from my wife.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Do you love her?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I do, actually; very much.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: You give me hope, John.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Soon.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I have to ask- why do you need me?

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: You like him, don't you?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Oh yes. But it takes time.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: You've known him long?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Since his beard was red.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Thank you.  Why does he need you by him?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: He doesn't. He needs nobody. But we have hunted many times...  ...he knows I am afraid of lions...

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Three years I've worked for the railroad. Now I don't know why. It seemed a good idea once.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: I feel the same about the bridge. This country certainly didn't ask for it, doesn't need it.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: He has children?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Once...

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: Where is it?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Underneath.  Somewhere.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Afraid of lions.

turns.speaker: PATTERSON
turns.text: It's all right, Samuel- we all get hit-

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Why do you laugh?- you don't believe she taught me?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: I don't believe you had a mother.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: How many cattle?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Four should do it.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: They will want a lot of money.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Why so many?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Because I have two plans to kill the lions- one involving the cattle, the other the men.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Did you ever see a lion that size?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Not even close.  What happened?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Gentlemen, there's no sickness smell at all here, and little blood. When we leave, close the gate securely, don't open it til morning and keep your fires high. Any questions, ask them now.  You two will sleep beautifully in your tents.  And stay there.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: And where will you sleep beautifully?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Patterson and I will be in the old hospital- where the enticing smell of sickness still lingers-  -and by the time we're done, I promise you, the odor of blood will be irresistible.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Where do you go next?

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Some Russian princes want to hunt the Himalayas. You?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Help finish the railroad.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: My life was shaped because someone invented gunpowder. Our lives have crossed because two lions went mad. But what if in the future the three of us do something grand for humanity? Was that worth all the lives? Too soon to tell.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Some mysteries should not have solutions.

turns.speaker: REDBEARD
turns.text: Hold your son high.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Oh, yes, I got in a little late this morning, Janosz.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: You know, you are really doing very good work here.  I think soon you may be ready to assist me in some of the more important restorations.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Thank you, Janosz.  I've learned a lot here, but now that my baby's a little older, I was hoping to rejoin the orchestra.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: We'll be very sorry to lose you.  Perhaps I could take you to lunch today?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Actually, I'm not eating lunch today.  I have an appointment.  In fact, I'd better go.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Every day I ask you, and every day you've got something else to do.  Do I have bad breath or something?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I'm sorry.  Perhaps some other time.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Okay, I'll take a raincheck on that.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Janosz?

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Hello, Dana.  I happened to be in the neighborhood and I thought I'd stop by to see if everything's all right with you -- you know, with the blackout and everything? Are you okay?  Is the baby all right?

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Do you need anything?  You want me to come in?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: No, everything's fine.  Honestly.  Thanks anyway.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Okay, just thought I'd check.  Good night, Dana.  Sleep well.  Don't let the bedbugs bite you.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Good night, Janosz.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Dana, aren't you going to introduce me to your friend?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry.  This is Peter Venkman. Peter, Janosz Poha.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: What do you want with my baby?

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: No harm will come to the child.  You might even say it's a privilege.  He will be the vessel for the spirit of Vigo.  And you -- well, you will be the mother of the ruler of the world.  Doesn't that sound nice?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: If this is what the world will be like, I don't want to live in it.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: I don't believe we have the luxury of choice.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Everybody has a choice.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Not in this case, my dear.  Take a look. That's not Gainsborough's Blue Boy up there. He's Vigo!

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I don't care who he is.  He's not taking my baby.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Time is running out, Dana.  Soon it will be midnight and the city will be mine -- and Vigo's.  Well, mainly Vigo's.  But we have a spectacular opportunity to make the best of our relationship.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: We don't have a relationship.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: I know.  Marry me, Dana, and together we will raise Vigo as our son.  There are many perks that come with being the mother of a living god.  I'm sure he will supply for us a magnificent apartment.  And perhaps a car and free parking.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I hate and despise you and everything you stand for with all my heart and soul.  I could never forgive what you've done to me and my child.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Many marriages begin with a certain amount of distance, but after a while I believe we could learn to love each other.  Think about it.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I'd rather not.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Hundreds of people.  Believe me, I didn't imagine this.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I'm not saying you did.  In science we always look for the simplest explanation.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: What are you working on, Egon?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I'm trying to determine whether human emotional states have a measurable effect on the psychomagnetheric energy field.  It's a theory Ray and I were working on when we had to dissolve Ghostbusters.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: We'll do the happiness index next.  I'd like to bring Ray in on your case, if it's all right with you.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Okay, whatever you think -- but not Venkman.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Oh no.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Do you ever see him?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Occasionally

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: How is he these days?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Venkman?  I think he was borderline for a while there.  Then he crossed the border.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Does he ever mention me?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: No.  Not that I can recall.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: This is my address and telephone number. Will you call me?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Certainly.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Egon, I'd rather you didn't mention any of this to Peter if you don't mind.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I won't.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Frank, do you think you could give me a hand with these bags?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm not a doorman, Miss Barrett.  I'm a building superintendent.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: You're also a human being, Frank.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay, okay.  It's not my job, but what the hell.  I'll do you a favor.  He takes the grocery bags from her.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Thank you, Frank.  I'll get the hang of this eventually.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hiya, Oscar.  What do you say, slugger?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's a good-looking kid you got there, Ms. Barrett.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Thank you, Frank.  Oh, are you ever going to fix the radiator in my bedroom?  I asked you last week.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Didn't I do it?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: No, you didn't, Frank.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay, that's no problem.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: That's exactly what you said last week.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Hello, Peter.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You know, Dana, I'm very very hurt that you didn't call me first.  I'm still into all this stuff, you know.  Haven't you ever seen my show?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I have.  That's why I didn't call you first.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I can see that you're still very bitter about us, but in the interest of science, I'm going to give it my best shot.  Let's go to work, boys.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: So what happened to Mr. Right?  I hear he ditched you and the kid and moved to Europe.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: He didn't "ditch" me.  We had some problems, he got a good offer from an orchestra in England and he took it.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: He ditched you.  You should've married me, you know.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: You never asked me, and every time I brought it up you'd get drowsy and fall asleep.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Men are very sensitive, you know.  We need to feel loved and desired, too.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Well, when you started introducing me as "the old ball and chain," that's when I left.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I may have a few personal problems but one thing I am is a total professional.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: There's no doubt about it.  He's got his father's looks.  The kid is ugly -- extremely ugly.  And smelly.  You stink!  It's just horrible.  You are the stinkiest baby I ever smelled.  What's his name?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: His name is Oscar.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Oscar!  You poor kid!

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Peter, this is serious.  I need to know if you think there's anything unusual about him.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Unusual?  I don't know.  I haven't had a lot of experience with babies.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I'll do it.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'll supervise.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Brings back a lot of sweet memories, doesn't it?  There's our old cash machine.  And the dry cleaners we used to go to.  And the old video store.  We really had some good times, didn't we?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: We definitely had a moment or two.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: That's where the buggy stopped.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Okay, let's take a look.
